_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Removed three reciprocating compressors and and four evaporators.  Replaced the -40F Recirculator and installed one screw compressor, four Blast Cell evaporators, and two convertible evaporators.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Visual inspection of the entire system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Arctic Cold Storage's senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The facility maintains a Safety Committee whose members are the designated emergency commanders for the facility.   Arctic Cold Storage has an Emergency Action Plan (Plan) in effect, which is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document maintained at the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate any facility changes.

Arctic Cold Storage has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department and with the contracted refrigeration operation and maintenance firm.  In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of Arctic Cold Storage to evacuate and to allow the fire department/HazMat Team to respond to the emergency.  The refrigeration contractor will be available for guidance and assistance.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE 

Arctic Cold Storage is located at 4139 Roosevelt Road, in St. Cloud, Minnesota.  The facility is approximately 0.45 miles north of Interstate 94, approximately 3.9 miles east of Highway 15, and approximately 50 feet east of Co. Rd. 75.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural with a mixture of light commercial and industrial areas.  The facility began operations in 1980 and added a second ammonia system in 2006.

The primary business of Arctic Cold Storage is to provide cooling

and storage of food products. The regulated material present at the facility and the focus of this study is ammonia.  The facility employs two independent refrigeration systems that contain approximately 9,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia each, as a refrigerant within a closed system.  However, the two systems' combined inventory, 18,000 pounds, exceeds 10,000 pounds and the systems are being considered as 'co-located' processes for the purposes of the Risk Management Plan regulation.  The systems, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for dock operations and cooler/freezer storage.  Typical operating conditions range from approximately 8"Hg on the low pressure side of the systems to 165 psig on the high side. 

Old System

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the Thermosyphon/High Pressure Receiver to the +15F Economizer and -40F Recirculator.  The liquid is subcooled in the +15A?aF Economizer as it flows through coils immersed in a bath of the liquid ammonia within the vessel.  The subcooled liquid ammonia is routed to evaporators in the Convertible Rooms, Dock, and Storage areas.  Liquid ammonia from the bath in the +15F Economizer is fed to the -20F Recirculator.  The -20F and -40F Recirculators pump liquid ammonia to evaporators located in the Storage Freezer and Blast Cell, respectively.  

Fans in each evaporator are used to blow air across and through the coils which partially vaporizes the liquid ammonia as heat from the room is transferred to the ammonia.  The resulting two-phased (liquid/vapor) ammonia from each evaporator returns to the vessel which supplied it.  (The exception is the Convertible evaporators which return two-phased ammonia to the -20F Recirculator or +15F Economizer, depending on opera

ting conditions.)  The liquid falls to the bottom of the vessel (to be reused in the evaporators) and the vapor is drawn from the top by the compressors.

There are three screw compressors (HS-4, HS-5, and HS-6) in the refrigeration system.  Compressor HS-6 draws vapor from the -40F Recirculator and the +15F Economizer, and HS-4 and HS-5 draw vapor from the -20F Recirculator and economizer suction from the +15F Economizer.  In addition, HS-4 has the capacity to draw vapor from the -40F Recirculator.  The pressure of the vapor is increased and then it is discharged through a common header to the Condensers, where the vapor is condensed to a high pressure liquid and drained back to the Thermosphon/High Pressure Receiver.  Compressor discharge (hot-gas) is also used for defrost of the evaporators.  

An Auto Purger periodically purges the system of non-condensibles collected in the Condensers. Dual pressure relief valve assemblies are installed on each vessel (set at 250 psig on all vessels, except for Compressor HS-4 & HS-5 oil separator relief valves which are set at 300 psig) to relieve high pressure ammonia to the atmosphere in case of a high pressure event. 

New System

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the High Pressure Receiver to the +15F Recirculator.  The High Pressure Receiver also provides liquid ammonia to the compressors for liquid injection oil cooling.  As the ammonia enters the +15F Recirculator, it is expanded through a hand expansion valve, reducing the pressure (and hence the temperature) in order to maintain a predetermined internal pressure.  The +15F Recirculator vessel pumps liquid ammonia to the dock (5) and cold storage evaporators (2).  Fans in each evaporator are used to blow air across and through the coils which partially vaporizes the liquid ammonia as heat from the room is transferred to the ammonia.  The resulting two-phased (liquid/vapor) ammonia from each evaporator is returned to t

he +15F Recirculator where constant pressures (temperatures) are maintained based on the suction pressure of the compressors. 

The +15F Recirculator also supplies liquid to the -20F Recirculator.  At the -20F Recirculator, the ammonia is further expanded through a hand expansion valve, reducing the pressure (and hence the temperature).  The -20F Recirculator vessel pumps liquid ammonia to the freezers (6) and the resulting two-phased (liquid/vapor) ammonia is returned to the same vessel.  In addition to the above, there are two evaporators which can operate in either a cold or freezer storage mode.

The vapor from both the +15F Recirculator and the -20F Recirculator is then drawn to three high stage screw compressors where the pressure and temperature of the gas is increased.  All three of the compressors are screw-type compressors which pull vapor from the vessels and discharge through a common header to the Condenser where the vapor is condensed to a high pressure liquid and drained back to the High Pressure Receiver.  Compressor discharge (hot gas) is also used for defrost of the evaporators.  An Auto Purger periodically purges the system of non-condensibles collected in the Condenser and High Pressure Receiver.  Dual pressure relief valve assemblies are installed on each vessel (set at 250 psig on all vessels, except for the compressor oil separator relief valves which are set at 300 psig) to relieve high pressure ammonia to the atmosphere in case of a high pressure event.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS 

The Arctic Cold Storage ammonia refrigeration systems have many safety features.  Much of the safety of the systems is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the Arctic cold Storage facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation.  Refrigeration contractors, experts in the ammonia refrigeration industry, are contracted at the

facility to maintain the system and perform any repairs.

The Arctic Cold Storage facility including each ammonia system was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  These safety features include ammonia sensor in the engine rooms as well as sensors in the cold storage areas, and automatic shut down system  that prevent equipment damage and ammonia releases.  In addition, the majority of the ammonia inventory is maintained inside the machine room and just outside of the machine room (condensers).  All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that automatically engage in case of a high pressure situation and vent through a common header to the atmosphere.

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration System."

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

There have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in the past five years (February 2006 to February 2011).  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

Arctic Cold Storage has an emergency response plan in effect at the facility. The Emergency Evacuation and Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document maintained at the facility. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives: 

1.)    To save lives. 
2.)    To minimize and avoid injuries. 
3.)    To protect the environment.
4.)    To minimize property damage. 

The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia he

alth hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM/RMP regulations.  

If a release of ammonia were to occur, Arctic cold Storage will determine the extent of the emergency.  The alarms are tied into the ammonia sensors and will automatically alarm.  Arctic Cold Storage management will determine if an evacuation is necessary.  They will call 911 in order to reach the appropriate HazMat Team who will resond to the ammonia release.  Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Action Plan. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

A Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation (PHA) was conducted on February 16, 2011 to further improve the safety at the Arctic Cold Storage facility in St. Cloud, Minnesota.  The PHA was comprised of one session that included a discussion of any changes to the ammonia refrigeration system since the 2006 PHA, a detailed review of the recommended action items generated during the 2006 Process Hazard Analysis and the 2009 PSM/RMP Three-Year Compliance Audit, a discussion of the facility's accident history dating back five years, completion of industry checklists, a site inspection to review the piping diagrams, review of the worst case and alternative case release scenarios, and review of the RMP*Submit.  The recommended changes from the PHA Revalidation study are scheduled to be completed by February 2012.

In addition, the facility is planning to complete several items over the next year as their continued effort to provide a safe work environment for Arctic Cold Storage employees in St. Cloud, Minnesota.  These changes include the following items:

1.    Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility's safety programs.
2.    Continue to have employee involvement in up

dating and refining Process Safety Management and the facility's safety programs.
3.    Continue employee involvement through the Employee Participation program.
4.    Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
